data.title: This is art?
data.text: I recently visited this place.   What a joke.   The art looked like stuff you could find in a thrift store or a preschool class room.  If someone offered anything in this museum to me for free, I wouldn't take anything.  First floor was nothing but a restaurant (if you can call it that) and a gift shop which was disappointing like the rest of the place.   The second and third floor had thrift store quality art.  Can't believe they have to have security guards guarding this stuff.  I don't think they have to worry about anybody running off with the art.   They might have to worry about someone writing "this art sucks" on it though.  If you want to check this place out, go on the first full weekend of each month when you get in free if you work for Bank of America or you are a Bank of America card holder.   Only come when it's free.   You'll be wasting your money if you go at any other time.   Obviously, the people who wrote all the good reviews on here are those that work at the museum and want to keep their job.

data.title: Inspiring collection!
data.text: The museum exhibits are wonderfully curated. The layout over three floors with open spaces is beautiful. There are special community programs and a nice shop that features some local artists work.

data.title: Enjoyed it!
data.text: Really nice contemporary works of art, one so huge as to blow one's mind! Lots of color and talent in this place.

owner_response.author: MOCAjax, Public Relations Manager at Museum of Contemporary Art Jacksonville, responded to this review
owner_response.title: Owner Response

data.title: The Air Conditioning is Wonderful
data.text: Finding parking is a nightmare. The building looks big but there really isn't much art being exhibited there. The 1st floor is a shop & restaurant. The next 2 floors are art. Above that, I have no idea what is up there because of the security guards. I've been here a few times & sometimes there is interesting art. But maybe contemporary art just isn't my thing. The security guards are really intimidating & extremely unfriendly. I don't know why. You leave feeling like you did something wrong. There isn't much to look at, but it did have great air conditioning. I probably won't go back.

data.title: interesting museum very creative and also great lunch place
data.text: i love MOCA, i had my wedding party in it, it was fantastic to do that in a museum, the set up was perfect, but i keep going to all sorts of events, it is a very active museum, right in the heart of Jacksonville

data.title: Good Museum
data.text: I visited during two special exhibitions that involved printmaking -- James Rosenquist and Andy Warhol. Both good and I saw a few Warhols I'd never seen before. The cell phone audio tour, while a little quirky in places, was excellent. The permanent collection is interesting as well.

data.title: Worth a visit
data.text:
I haven't been in years. I am slowly learning about modern art and having become more willing to try. I am so glad we went when we did - Warhol and Rosenquist. I know Warhol's works but Rosenquist was a great discovery for me. 

I met some of the staff. A security guard stopped to give us a critical analysis of some of Rosenquist's work. The people were friendly and recommended a local place since we were to late for the museum's cafe.

data.title: Hardly any art, berated for breastfeeding
data.text: I definitely disagree with the previous reviews. This museum has five floors, but only two floors are dedicated to art installations. The first floor is the restaurant and gift shop, the fourth floor is only administrative offices, and the fifth floor is the children's area (with a photography installation currently residing on the way to the restroom). That leaves only the second and third floors. They are not large rooms. The second floor is the museums permanent installation, and the third floor changes. It is currently the Andy Warhol floor. I saw all of the art there was to see in less than 40 mins, but I'm sure that some people see it faster. My son had fun at the play area, and we spent a half hour there. My biggest complaint comes from how I was treated by the female security guard who walked up on me breastfeeding my son. We arrived as soon as the museum opened, and we were literally the only patrons in the whole building. My son was hungry, so I sat on the only bench I could find started nursing him. The security guard walked over from across the room and said "..Oh!! Oh. You know we have a nursing room for that, right? On the fifth floor. So I suggest you go use that. Now." And she stood there next to me until I got up and left. I decided to check out that nursing room she was talking about...it was just the ladies bathroom.

data.title: Very interesting place for family, friends or visitors
data.text: There is so much to see and do in this multi-story facility.  To enjoy the entire museum, plan to spend at least 6 hours.

data.title: Pleasantly Surprised
data.text: We were pleasantly surprised w the amount and variety of the exhibits. We went on a BOA free Saturday, otherwise it would have been too pricey for what it had to offer.

data.title: Nice revolving displays
data.text: Many interactive events for teachers/students, art lovers will enjoy the stroll and everyone needs to learn to appreciate different ways people express themselves.

data.title: kids love art
data.text: this place has an awesome kids area upstairs.  we usuall park at the king street garage and take the skyway to hemming plaze and MOCA is right there.  what a great, cheap way to experience downtown and the life of the city.  We also have left MOCA and walked a few blocks to the Bank of America building.  they have a cafe on the very top floor.  very cool to see all of downtown from one of the tallest buildings in jacksonville.

data.title: A surprising find in the city
data.text: My husband and I like to go on "adventures" where we live, to get to know the area better.  We had been meaning to go to MOCA, but never seemed to get there.  Well, we went today and while two floors had exhibits under construction, we were surprised to find out that MOCA is part of the University of North Florida.  But the exhibits are not only by curated senior art students and staff, but they have pieces from Warhol, Lichtenstein and other notables.  There is also an interactive gallery for children and families.  Café Nola was closed while we were there, but is known for its innovative cuisine.  Maybe we'll be able to try it next visit!  The museum's website gives directions for parking, but on the weekends, street parking is free and we were able to find a spot just around the corner from the entrance.  This is a hidden gem and whether a resident or visiting, don't miss this one!

data.title: NOT KID FRIENDLY
data.text:
I went with my 13 and 10 year old boys. I had read other reviews about the art and the front desk subtly "warned" me about the nude art on the second floor.  However being the parent I feel I'm best to make the call on what my kids can handle.  
So we went to the second floor, and I noticed that a security guard was behind us. Ok, no big deal.  So we went to the third floor where the Smoke and Mirrors exhibit was displayed. We come upon some kind of class which was blocking the entrance to the exhibit. Once again we see the security guard........ Hmmmmmmm........  So we go to another part of the floor and guess what!  That's right, the security guard was there again!
At this point I went downstairs to the front desk to get our entrance fee back. I will give them credit for the fact they refunded my money immediately and without any hassle. 
I will say this, I don't think I would have been followed if I didn't have kids.

data.title: Modern art in an old building
data.text: A tired and hackneyed collection of 'modern' art in an equally bland setting. Uninspiring inspiration at its best, which is into what Jacksonville excels.

data.title: Very Cool
data.text: The space had a lot of cool exhibits. I would definitely come back. Very cool and fun museum. Great for kids.

data.title: A Less Unknown Treasure in Jacksonville to visit...
data.text: I visited the Jacksonville Art Walk last week and discovered an exhibit in downtown Jacksonville worth seeing at the Museum of Contemporary Art.  It was absolutely amazing to explore the exhibit of "Illusions" on the third floor.  All grandparents with time on their hands, should take their grandkids around the age of 9 to 13 to experience this exhibit.  I'm just over 65 years of age and was very surprised to see how far the visual arts have come.  Please be aware though, there is a painting on another floor that might be somewhat offensive to the younger viewers.  But, do take the kids to see the arts and crafts on the "children's floor".  Our kids needs to experience this "creative" exposure on that floor.

data.title: Exceeded expectations
data.text: Let's face it, there is not a whole deal to do in downtown Jacksonville on a humid and hot Sunday if you don't have transportation so more by accident than by design, we ended up visiting the Museum of Contemporary Art. What a joy it was though! The collection is indeed not large but it is very well set out and the temporary exhibition (Smoke and Mirrors) was brilliant and thought-provoking. Very nice shop too, with very friendly and helpful staff, and the cafe looked nice although we did not eat there. All in all, a very enjoyable and memorable couple of hours spent.

data.title: Best field trip ever
data.text: The first time i went here was in seventh grade for a field trip, The second time i went ( nearly six years later) was even better, i definitely recommend giving MOCA a visit when ever you're in the area

data.title: GO!
data.text:
Always happily surprised by the interesting exhibitions. Very up-to-date in the art field.
As the Museum is not very big, you can visit the whole of it in a visit.
The little shop is also faithful to the Museum's vocation.
